# Scalar SDE Analytical Solution
This is Exercise 8.1 from [@sarkka2019applied].
We are given the following SDE:
\begin{equation}
\D x = -c \, x \D t + g \, x \D \beta, \quad x(0) = x_0,
\end{equation}
where \(c\), \(g\), and \(x_0\) are positive constants and \(\beta (t)\) is a standard Brownian motion.

We will use the It√¥ chain rule, where the drift function is \(F(x) = -cx\) and the dispersion function \(G(x) = gx\).
We want to solve for \(u(x) = \ln{\left( x\right)}\).
\begin{align}
u_t &= 0\\
u_x &= \dfrac{1}{x}\\
u_{xx} &= - \dfrac{1}{x^2}\\
\implies \D u &= \left(u_t + u_x F + \dfrac{1}{2} u_{xx} G^2 \right) \D t + u_x \,G \,\D \beta\\
&=\left(0 - \dfrac{cx}{x} - \dfrac{g^2 x^2}{2x^2} \right) \D t + \dfrac{gx}{x} \, \D \beta\\
&=\left(- c - \dfrac{g^2}{2} \right) \D t + g \, \D \beta\\
\implies u &= \left(- c - \dfrac{g^2}{2} \right) t + g \beta + C\\
\ln{\left( x \right)} &= \left(- c - \dfrac{g^2}{2} \right) t + g \beta + C\\
\implies x &= C \exp{\left[ \left(- c - \dfrac{g^2}{2} \right) t + g \beta \right]}\\
\text{Applying the initial condition,}\quad\quad x &= x_0 \exp{\left[ \left(- c - \dfrac{g^2}{2} \right) t + g \beta \right]}
\end{align}

# Numerical Solution
We will examine the case where \(x_0 = 1, \, c = 0.1, \, g=0.1\) with the Milstein method.
The SDE, therefore, is
\begin{equation}
\D x = -0.1x \D t + 0.1 x \D \beta, \quad x(0) = 1.
\end{equation}
and the known analytical solution is:
\begin{equation}
x = \exp{\left[ -0.105 \right]t + 0.1 \beta}
\end{equation}
